title-group.article-title: Translation and validation of the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (BSS-RI) in Chinese

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/006teas31grid.39436.3b0000 0001 2323 5732Affiliated Nantong Hospital of Shanghai University（The Sixth People’s Hospital of Nantong), Nantong, Jiangsu China 226011

abstract.p: The study aimed to translate and validate the Chinese version of the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (C-BSS-RI) and assess its psychometric properties. Conducted from April to August 2023 at three hospitals in Nantong, China, it included 824 mothers. Exploratory factor analysis revealed a two-factor structure with eigenvalues greater than 1, explaining 63.384% of the variance. Confirmatory factor analysis showed good model fit with the Chi-square/Df (χ2/Df) ratio = 1.511, root mean square error of approximation = 0.035, comparative fit index = 0.989, tucker-lewis index = 0.979, and normed fit index = 0.968. The C-BSS-RI demonstrated strong convergent validity with significant correlations between the total score and satisfaction questions. Divergent validity was confirmed by non-significant correlations between the Quality of Care sub-scale and maternal age. The C-BSS-RI total score showed significant negative correlations with measures of postpartum depression, anxiety, and stress, supporting the association between birth satisfaction and postpartum psychological states. Known-groups discriminant validity was confirmed with significant differences in C-BSS-RI scores across different modes of delivery. The internal consistency of the total scale was α = 0.76, the Stress of Childbearing sub-scale was α = 0.74, and the Quality of Care sub-scale was α = 0.66, indicating good reliability. The C-BSS-RI is a reliable and valid tool for assessing birth satisfaction among Chinese women.

funding-source.institution: The scientific research projects of Nantong Commission of Health

institution-wrap.institution: Social Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The importance of women having a positive experience of pregnancy and childbirth is emphasized in both intrapartum care1 and the World Health Organization’s guidelines for antenatal2. However, historically, maternity care has primarily concentrated on physical outcomes such as morbidity and mortality, neglecting the emotional aspects3. The experience of childbirth for a woman can have direct and long-lasting effects on her overall well-being. Positive experiences are essential in both normal and complex childbirth as they can enhance a woman’s physical, psychological, and social well-being4. In addition, a woman’s satisfaction with her birth experience can have an impact on the health and well-being of herself and her newborn, as well as their relationships5. Therefore, assessing the satisfaction of women during childbirth and the postpartum period with obstetric services can help policymakers enhance the quality of healthcare services6.

Birth satisfaction is a multifaceted concept that holds significant importance to a woman’s perception of her birth experience7. Although structured interviews are commonly utilized to evaluate the satisfaction of women during childbirth, they can be time-consuming and necessitate the involvement of trained professionals to conduct them8. Self-reported measures are considered a valuable and effective initial method for screening and early detection of birth satisfaction. These measures are relatively easier to administer. Numerous assessment tools have been employed to evaluate birth satisfaction5,9. However, it is important to note that some of these instruments have faced criticism for their limited alignment with the underlying theoretical framework7. The assessment of birth satisfaction presents a multidimensional and challenging task due to the variability in individuals’ personal preferences and expectations10. Various assessment tools have been developed to gauge the level of satisfaction individuals experience during birth. However, Sawyer et al. emphasized that several measures utilized to evaluate satisfaction with the birth experience were not rooted in the primary theoretical models of satisfaction7.

The Chinese version of the Childbirth Experience Questionnaire (CEQ)11 is a widely used questionnaire to assess women’s satisfaction with childbirth in China. Although the Chinese CEQ is a reliable and valuable measure of childbirth experience following vaginal birth, its length (22 items) may present practical challenges for rapid screening in high-volume clinical settings12. Critically, it is not validated for use after cesarean delivery11. Consequently, there is a need for concise, validated assessment tools applicable across all delivery modes to facilitate efficient screening of birth satisfaction13.

Hollins Martin and Fleming developed the Birth Satisfaction Scale (BSS), a self-report questionnaire, to evaluate women’s perspectives on the birth experience. The initial version of BSS consists of 30 items in English and was designed to be inclusive and applicable within the birth context. The development process involved reviewing relevant research literature and incorporating evidence-based insights concerning women’s satisfaction with the birthing experience14. Following the 30 items version, a shorter 10-item form of the scale was developed known as the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised (BSS-R). This abbreviated version focuses on three distinct domains: Quality of Care, Women’s Attributes, and Stress Experienced15. Although both the BSS and BSS-R were found to be valid and reliable measures of psychological dimensions of satisfaction, there was a desire to simplify the instrument by reducing the number of items while still maintaining its effectiveness as an indicator. This led to the development of the six-item version known as the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (BSS-RI), which demonstrated excellent psychometric properties when tested in the UK population. The BSS-RI provides a user-friendly and psychologically plausible means of assessing birth satisfaction16. The BSS-RI is a 6-item questionnaire that includes two sub-scales: stress experienced during childbearing (BSS-RI-SE) and quality of care (BSS-RI-QC). As the significance of childbirth satisfaction in clinical outcomes gains recognition, there is an increasing demand for short, valid, reliable, and theoretically grounded measures like the BSS-RI. However, at present, the BSS-RI has only been translated into the Iranian language17.

Given the significance and utility of the BSS-RI, and the limited availability of short assessment tools to measure birth satisfaction among the Chinese population, there is a need to develop and validate a Chinese-language version of the BSS-RI. The objective of this study is to create a Chinese version of the BSS-RI that can effectively evaluate women’s childbirth experiences in China, thus contributing to the existing body of research in this field. The BSS-RI is a 6-item questionnaire that includes two subscales: Stress Experienced during Childbirth (SE) and Quality of Care (QC). The aim of this study is to validate and adopt the BSS-RI in the Chinese language in China.

sec.title: 2.1. Design and participants.
sec.p: This cross-sectional study was conducted among postpartum women who underwent physical examinations six weeks after delivery. Data collection took place between April and August 2023 at three tertiary hospitals in Nantong City, China: The Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University, The Sixth People’s Hospital of Nantong, and The Affiliated Maternity and Child Health Care Hospital of Nantong University. The three hospitals selected for this study are situated in different regions of Nantong City, ensuring a representative sample of postpartum women from across the area. The timing of the study, six weeks postpartum, was chosen to provide a comprehensive assessment of birth satisfaction while minimizing potential threats to care and aligning with established postnatal care practices18,19.

Participants were selected using convenience sampling. In our study, the sample size calculation was based on the formula for cross-sectional studies, considering the snapshot nature of our research. Given the lack of local data on the prevalence of birth satisfaction measured by the BSS-RI, we assumed a prevalence of 60% (P = 0.6) with reference to international validation studies of similar scales. The calculation formula was: N = Z2 × P(1-P) / e2. Where Z = 1.96 (95% confidence level), P = 0.6 (assumed prevalence), and e = 0.05 (margin of error). The calculation yielded a minimum sample size of 368.8. Considering a 10% potential attrition rate, the adjusted required sample size was 406. This study is part of a broader research project titled “Comprehensive Assessment of Physical and Mental Health Among Pregnant Women and New Mothers,” which aims to gather extensive data on various aspects of physical and mental health. Fortunately, our recruitment rate exceeded expectations, and we were able to gather a total of 836 participants for our study, meeting the sample size criteria. However, two participants withdrew from the study, eight had incomplete data, and two provided invalid responses. As a result, the final analysis included 824 participants, resulting in a response rate of 98.56%. To assess test–retest reliability, a random subsample of 30 participants was recruited from the baseline cohort. Retesting was conducted 2 weeks after initial assessment, an interval selected to minimize recall bias while assuming stable birth satisfaction perceptions20,21. The sample size was determined in accordance with COSMIN guidelines for reliability studies, which specify that ≥ 25 subjects provides adequate precision for intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) estimation22,23.

The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) Postpartum women aged 18 years or older, (2) Mothers of newborns with no birth defects or severe complications, (3) Willingness to participate in the survey, (4) Ability to communicate effectively in Chinese and understand the questionnaire content, (5) Ability to complete the questionnaire independently. The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) Presence of mental illnesses, (2) Presence of severe organic diseases (e.g., severe cardiovascular diseases, chronic respiratory diseases, or other conditions that significantly impact physical health).

Before the survey commenced, all participants were informed about the purpose, methods, and significance of the study. They were provided with standardized instructions that included a comprehensive overview of the investigation’s purpose and content. They were also informed that their participation was voluntary, and all responses would be kept confidential. They had the option to withdraw from participation at any time. The entire survey lasted for 10–15 min. The study obtained ethical approval from the Research Ethics Committee of the Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University (approval number: 2022-K150-01).

To ensure that the selection of a limited number of items from the BSS-RI did not significantly impact the measure’s conceptual alignment, we employed a random split-half data selection procedure24,25. This procedure involved dividing the dataset into two random halves: one for exploratory factor analysis (EFA) to identify the underlying factor structure, and the other for confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) to validate the identified structure. This approach is consistent with best practices in instrument development and evaluation.

sec.title: Birth Satisfaction Scale-revised indicator, BSS-RI
sec.p: BSS-RI16 is an instrument that has been proven to be both reliable and valid in measuring self-reported birth satisfaction, consisting 6 items and dividing into 2 sub-scales: stress of childbearing (BSS-RI-SE) (4 items) and quality of care (BSS-RI-QC) (2 items). Each item is rated on a 3-point Likert scale, where respondents can select from the options of ‘agree’, ‘agree to some degree’, or ‘disagree’. Higher scores indicate higher levels of birth satisfaction, with the scoring system ranging from 0 to 12.

sec.title: Scales used to assess postpartum psychological states
sec.p: To assess the correlation between the C-BSS-RI and postpartum psychological states, we used the following scales: (1) Maternal Postpartum Stress Scale (MPSS): A 22-item scale measuring postpartum stress, scored on a 5-point Likert scale26. (2) Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS): A 10-item scale evaluating postpartum depression, scored from 0 to 327. (3) Depression Anxiety Stress Scale (DASS-21): A 21-item scale assessing depression, anxiety, and stress, with each sub-scale consisting of 7 items28.

sec.title: Translation of the BSS-RI
sec.p: We have administered the questionnaires in Chinese to the participants. After obtaining authorization from the original author, the BSS-RI was translated into Chinese using the classic “backward and forward” approach, following the improved Brislin translation model29. The forward translation of the English items into Chinese was carried out independently by two bilingual Chinese native psychologists. Then, the researcher and the translator discussed and revised the scale, and reached a consensus to put forward the Chinese version of the scale. Next, the reconciled forward version of the scale was translated back into English by two independent bilingual psychologists who were unfamiliar with the original English version. Finally, the original English version and the back-translated version were compared to one another in accordance with the cross-cultural adaptation guidelines of the scale30. The translated versions were carefully examined and evaluated by a panel of six experts, including psychologists, clinical experts, nursing education experts, sociologists, and obstetric nursing experts. The results of the evaluation indicated that the translated versions maintained semantic equivalence with the original version. Afterwards, a total of 30 postpartum women participated in cognitive interviews to assess the comprehensibility of the Chinese version of the BSS-RI. Based on their feedback, revisions were made to improve its clarity and understanding31.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: In our study, we used Kendall W analysis to assess the concordance among expert reviewers. Additionally, we calculated the Content Validity Index (CVI) to evaluate the relevance and appropriateness of each scale item. The CVI was calculated using a panel of expert reviewers who rated each item on a 4-point Likert scale. The item-level CVI (I-CVI) was calculated by dividing the number of experts who rated the item as 3 or 4 by the total number of experts. The scale-level CVI (S-CVI) is calculated as the average of all I-CVI values. We conducted an EFA to assess the factor structure of the BSS-RI. The data were split into two random halves to ensure that the factor structure was robust and not overfitted to the data. One half was used for EFA, and the other half for CFA. The suitability of the data for factor analysis will be evaluated using the Kaiser–Meyer–Olkin (KMO) measure and Bartlett’s sphericity test32. Common factor analysis was chosen because it focuses on explaining the common variance among items, which is more appropriate for identifying latent factors in our study. We performed a CFA using Amos software (version 24.0) to validate the consistency of the model structure with the identified factor structure. The model’s goodness of fit was evaluated using several indices: the Chi-square/Df (χ2/Df) ratio, root mean square residual (RMR), root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), incremental fit index (IFI), normed fit index (NFI), and comparative fit index (CFI). A good model fit was indicated by a Chi-square/Df (χ2/Df) ratio less than 3, an RMSEA value less than 0.08, a CFI value greater than 0.90, a TLI value greater than 0.90, and an NFI value greater than 0.90. The CFA results showed a good model fit with χ2/Df = 1.511, RMSEA = 0.035, CFI = 0.989, TLI = 0.979, and NFI = 0.968, indicating that the model fits the data well and supports the validity of the C-BSS-RI.33. Internal consistency reliability was assessed using Cronbach’s α coefficient, with values exceeding 0.7 deemed acceptable16. The test–retest reliability of the C-BSS-RI sub-scale and total scores was assessed by calculating the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). This analysis involved comparing the scores obtained at baseline and follow-up within a subset of 30 participants from the baseline sample, selected using convenience sampling. The retesting was conducted 2 weeks after the initial assessment. We hypothesized that the ICC would be above 0.70, indicating good test–retest reliability. Differences in demographic characteristics between the EFA and CFA groups were assessed using the two-sided chi-squared test. Meanwhile, Student’s t-test was employed to evaluate differences in total BSS-RI scores among postpartum women with varying statuses. The correlation between birth satisfaction and postpartum psychological states was assessed using the EPDS, DASS-21, and MPSS scales. Convergent validity was assessed by correlating the C-BSS-RI total scores with a satisfaction question scored on a 1–5 scale (1 = ”very dissatisfied,” 5 = ”very satisfied”). We hypothesized a positive correlation, based on prior research linking positive birth experiences with reduced postpartum distress, and used Pearson’s correlation analysis to evaluate this relationship. Divergent validity was assessed by calculating Pearson’s correlation coefficients between the total and subscale scores of the C-BSS-RI and maternal age. We hypothesized that there would be no significant correlation between the C-BSS-RI scores and maternal age. Known-groups discriminant validity was evaluated by comparing C-BSS-RI scores across different types of delivery using one-way ANOVA. The Bonferroni test was used for post-hoc multiple comparisons. We compared scores among four distinct delivery modes: Natural Vaginal Delivery without Injury (NVD-WI), which refers to deliveries without any form of obstetric intervention or injury, Vaginal Delivery with Injury or Assistance (VD-WIA), which includes deliveries involving perineal tears, episiotomies, or the use of obstetric instruments such as forceps or vacuum extraction, Emergency Cesarean Section, which refers to cesarean deliveries performed due to unforeseen complications during labor, and Elective Cesarean Section, which refers to cesarean deliveries scheduled in advance without complications during labor16. We hypothesized that there would be significant differences in C-BSS-RI scores across these groups. Data analysis was conducted using SPSS 25.0 and Amos 24.0. A significance level of 0.05 (two-tailed) was chosen as the threshold for statistical significance.

sec.title: 3.1. Demographic information
sec.p:
824 Chinese women participants who gave birth within the past six weeks agreed to participate in this study. Participants mean age was 29.91 years (SD = 3.66), 75.4% are primiparous mothers, and the majority have an education level of bachelor or above. Characteristics of the participants in the EFA group (n = 412) and CFA group (n = 412) indicated comparability between the two groups for all variables (P > 0.05), as shown in Table 1. Table 2 presents a summary of the descriptive and distributional characteristics, as well as the scores of C-BSS-RI.Table 1

BSS-RI (Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator): A 6-item self-report questionnaire designed to assess women’s satisfaction with their birth experience. It includes two subscales: Stress of Childbearing (SE) and Quality of Care (QC).

sec.title: 3.2. Item analysis
sec.p:
The BSS-RI total scores of the 824 survey participants were sorted, where the top 27% were categorized as the high satisfaction group, while the bottom 27% were categorized as the low satisfaction group. The mean scores for each item were calculated for both groups. After conducting a two-tailed independent samples t-test, statistically significant differences were found between the two groups for individual items (P < 0.05). The specific statistical results can be found in Table 3. The results of the correlation analysis show that the Pearson’s correlation coefficients between each item and the total scale are all > 0.2, as shown in Table 4.Table 3
Item analysis (low-score groups = 222, high-score groups = 222).

BSS-RI 5− 44.338− 1.491< 0.001

BSS-RI (Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator): A 6-item self-report questionnaire designed to assess women’s satisfaction with their birth experience. It includes two subscales: Stress of Childbearing (SE) and Quality of Care (QC).Table 4

BSS-RI (Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator): A 6-item self-report questionnaire designed to assess women’s satisfaction with their birth experience.

sec.title: Content validity index (CVI)
sec.p: The CVI for each item in the C-BSS-RI ranged from 0.833 to 1, exceeding the acceptable threshold of 0.78. The scale’s cumulative CVI (S-CVI) was 0.972. An S-CVI of 0.80 or higher is typically considered to indicate good content validity. Our study’s S-CVI of 0.972 suggests that the C-BSS-RI has good content validity. The results showed a Kendall W value of 0.375 (P = 0.047), indicating statistically significant agreement among the experts.

sec.title: 3.1.1. EFA
sec.p:
The KMO measure was 0.765, and Bartlett’s sphericity test yielded a statistically significant result (χ2 = 606.194, P < 0.001), indicating the suitability of the data for factor structure analysis using the translated BSS-RI. Two factors with eigenvalues greater > 1 were extracted, explaining a total of 63.384% of the data discrepancies. Furthermore, the results of EFA indicated that all items had factor loadings greater > 0.4. As a result, it was determined that all items should be retained. For more detailed information, please refer to Table 5.Table 5
Exploratory factor analysis of the BSS-RI in Chinese version (N = 412).

BSS-RI (Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator): A 6-item self-report questionnaire designed to assess women’s satisfaction with their birth experience.

sec.title: 3.3.1.2. CFA
sec.p:
The results displayed in Fig. 1 demonstrated favorable fit, indicating a good alignment between the observed data and the theoretical model. The values of the indicators were χ2/Df = 1.511 (< 3), RMSEA = 0.035 (< 0.08), CFI = 0.989 (> 0.9), TLI = 0.979 (> 0.9), and NFI = 0.968 (> 0.9).Fig. 1
This figure presents the standardized factor loadings for the two-dimensional measurement model of the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (BSS-RI). The model includes two factors: Stress of Childbearing (SE) and Quality of Care (QC). Each item’s factor loading is displayed, indicating the strength of the relationship between each item and the underlying factors.

sec.title: Birth Satisfaction and Postpartum Psychological States
sec.p: The Pearson correlation coefficients of C-BSS-RI with EPDS, DASS-21 anxiety sub-scale and MPSS were− 0.338, − 0.299 and − 0.347, respectively (P < 0.001).

sec.title: Convergent validity
sec.p:
There was a significant correlation (P < 0.001) between the total C-BSS-RI score and two sub-scales, as well as the scores of satisfaction questions, indicating convergent validity. Please refer to Table 6 for details.Table 6
Spearman’s rho correlations between Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (BSS-RI) total score, subscale scores and satisfaction question (N = 824).
ScaleBSS-RI totalBSS-RI-SEBBS-RI-QCSatisfaction
BSS-RI total1
BSS-RI-SE0.959***1
BSS-RI-QC0.480***0.274***1
Satisfaction0.195***0.148***0.206***1
Key to subscales: stress experienced during labour (BSS-RI-SE), and quality of care provision (BSS-RI-QC) ***: p < 0.001 “Satisfaction” refers to the participants’ overall satisfaction with their childbirth experience.

sec.title: Divergent validity
sec.p: No significant correlation was observed between quality of care sub-scales score and participant age (r = 0.014, P = 0.689). However, significant correlations were observed between participant age and both the C-BSS-RI total score (r = 0.111, P = 0.001) and the stress of childbearing subscale scores (r = 0.117, P < 0.001).

sec.title: Known-groups discriminant validity
sec.p:
As shown in Table 7, there were statistically differences were observed in all total C-BSS-RI scales and sub-scales between groups divided by birth mode (P < 0.05). Women who chose elective cesarean section had the highest birth satisfaction scores, followed by natural vaginal delivery. The score of vaginal delivery with injury or assistance was significantly lower than that of natural vaginal delivery, and the score of emergency cesarean delivery was significantly lower than that of elective cesarean delivery.Table 7
Comparison of Chinese-BSS-RI total and subscale scores differentiated by mode of birth.
BSS-RI ScaleNatural vaginal delivery (n = 109) M (SD)Vaginal delivery with injury or assistance(n = 421) M(SD)Emergency Cesarean Section (n = 71) M(SD)Elective Cesarean Section (n = 223) M (SD)FP

BSS-RI (Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator): A 6-item self-report questionnaire designed to assess women’s satisfaction with their birth experience. It includes two subscales: Stress of Childbearing (SE) and Quality of Care (QC). In pairwise comparisons between groups, the same superscript letters indicate P > 0.05, while different superscript letters indicate P ≤ 0.05.

sec.title: Reliability analysis
sec.p: The total BSS-RI had a Cronbach’s α coefficient of 0.76, while the stress sub-scale had a coefficient of 0.74, and the quality sub-scale had a coefficient of 0.66. The test–retest reliability coefficient of 0.80 indicates that this scale possesses good reliability.

sec.title: Correlation between the total items of BSS-RI and each sub-scale
sec.p:
In terms of magnitude, the impact of each sub-scale of birth satisfaction on the total score of birth satisfaction was as follows: stress of childbearing (r = 0.959, P < 0.001) and quality of care (r = 0.543, P < 0.001). The correlation between the two sub-scales was (r = 0.285, P < 0.001). The relationship between each sub-scale and the overall BSS-RI item is shown in Fig. 2.Fig. 2
Correlation Between Total Items of C-BSS-RI and Each Subscale.This figure displays the Pearson correlation coefficients between the total items of the Chinese version of the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (C-BSS-RI) and its two sub-scales: Stress of Childbearing (SE) and Quality of Care (QC).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The primary objective of this study was to translate and validate the Chinese version of the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised Indicator (C-BSS-RI) and assess its psychometric properties. Our findings indicate that the C-BSS-RI demonstrates good reliability and validity, confirming its suitability as a translation of the original UK version of the BSS-RI16. The two-dimensional measurement model fit well, and the internal consistency of the total scale was acceptable. The C-BSS-RI total score and sub-scales showed strong evidence of convergent validity, and known-groups discriminant validity. These results suggest that the C-BSS-RI is a reliable and valid tool for assessing birth satisfaction among Chinese women.

Additionally, there was a weak association between the total score of the C-BSS-RI and participants’ age, with older women reporting higher birth satisfaction. Older mothers may benefit from stronger social networks and accumulated life experiences that enhance coping strategies during childbirth34. Older women often demonstrate greater familiarity with prenatal care systems and access to health information, potentially reducing uncertainty and stress35. The C-BSS-RI scores were significantly correlated with maternal age, but the effect sizes were small. This means that while there is a statistically detectable relationship, maternal age explains only a small portion of the variance in birth satisfaction scores. This supports the idea that the C-BSS-RI is a reliable tool for measuring birth satisfaction, as it is not heavily influenced by demographic factors like age.

As far as we are aware, this is the inaugural study examining the reliability and validity of the BSS-RI in Chinese mothers. The BSS-RI is a succinct and user-friendly instrument that presents a more efficient alternative in terms of resources compared to lengthier assessment measures. Similar to the UK sample, the quality of care items yielded the highest mean score on the BSS-RI. In addition, the mean of quality of care sub-scale scores (Mean = 3.67) was higher than the results reported for the UK sample (Mean = 3.46), and the mean of stress of childbearing sub-scale scores (Mean = 4.98) was also higher than the UK sample (Mean = 4.74)16. This suggests that Chinese mothers reported slightly higher birth satisfaction compared to mothers in the UK.

These findings not only validate the Birth Satisfaction Scale as a reliable measurement tool with known group validity but also emphasize the importance of the mode of delivery in determining women’s satisfaction with childbirth. C-BSS-RI total scale and sub-scale scores were significantly lower for assisted vaginal delivery or emergency cesarean section than for C-BSS-RI total scale and sub-scale scores for vaginal delivery or elective cesarean section. Compared to vaginal delivery, women with assisted vaginal delivery may experience less satisfaction with labor due to the pain and psychological shadow of vaginal injury caused by vulvar tear or forceps delivery. The reason for the higher satisfaction rate of cesarean delivery than vaginal delivery in our results may be that most cesarean deliveries are planned, the mothers are psychologically prepared, vaginal delivery experiences unpredictability and pain during labor, there is a sense of helplessness and fear during delivery, and the quality of delivery care provided cannot meet the requirements of vaginal delivery. Enhanced communication and shared decision-making before, during and after childbirth may therefore help women to be actively involved in their own childbirth36. Women are offered support and information when planning a cesarean section, which due to time constraints would not happen in emergency situations37. As a result, women may suffer psychological trauma after an emergency cesarean section that would not have happened if they had had time to plan and manage preparations for cesarean Sections38. Clearly, an emergency cesarean section is an unexpected event, and it’s not surprising that this can have detrimental effects on the birth experience39.

The results indicate that the internal consistency estimations of the Chinese version of the BSS-RI are generally reliable. The lower Cronbach’s α for the quality of care sub-scale, which consists of only two items, suggests that the reliability of this sub-scale may be limited due to the small number of items and did not meet the threshold levels for acceptable consistency. The two items in the quality of care sub-scale may not capture the full range of experiences related to the quality of care during childbirth, leading to a less consistent measurement. We selected the 6-item BSS-RI due to its brevity, which facilitates efficient administration in clinical settings. This version maintains robust psychometric properties, ensuring reliable assessment of birth satisfaction. Future research might explore expanding the quality of care sub-scale to enhance comprehensiveness.

The successful validation of the C-BSS-RI provides a valuable tool for assessing birth satisfaction among Chinese women. This instrument can be used to identify areas for improvement in maternity care and to develop targeted interventions aimed at enhancing the birth experience. The findings emphasize the importance of considering cultural and contextual factors in the assessment of birth satisfaction. Future research should consider longitudinal studies to better understand the dynamics of birth satisfaction over time and to explore the impact of different interventions on maternal satisfaction.

Finally, it is necessary to recognize that our study had certain limitations. Firstly, our study includes data from three hospitals in Nantong City, which may limit the generalizability of our findings. The proportion of assisted vaginal deliveries in our sample might not reflect the national average, as our study sites have specific characteristics that could influence delivery practices. Future research could benefit from including a wider range of hospitals to better represent the broader population. Secondly, our cross-sectional design restricts our ability to establish causal relationships between the BSS-RI scores and the demographic characteristics of the mothers. Additionally, future longitudinal studies should investigate whether birth satisfaction predicts long-term psychological outcomes. Lastly, in our future research, we plan to take into consideration and include participants who may not be representative, such as high-risk pregnant women or women who have experienced preterm birth.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The BSS-RI, originally in English, underwent a rigorous translation process to create a Chinese version. The reliability and validity of the translated version were assessed to confirm its psychometric properties. The Chinese version of the BSS-RI, which comprises 6 items and 2 sub-scales, has demonstrated well reliability and validity. Since its adapted to the Chinese culture, C-BSS-RI has been successfully employed in the assessment of postpartum women in China. The C-BSS-RI is expected to serve as a valuable tool in identifying postpartum women’s satisfaction with childbirth and developing targeted intervention measures. Consequently, the utilization of the C-BSS-RI in Chinese postpartum women not only holds clinical significance but also offers practical value in enhancing their overall physical and mental well-being.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors give thanks for all participants who volunteered to participate in this study.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: Y.W completed the writing of this article. J.G collected and analyzed the data. F.Z and J.D put forward important revision suggestions and made corresponding modifications for this article. All authors contributed to the article and approved the submitted version.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work was supported by Social Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province (22SHB014). The scientific research projects of Nantong Commission of Health (QN2023043). The funding sources had no role to play in the study design, the collection and interpretation of the data, writing of the report, or decision to submit this paper for publication.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The raw data of the current study would be available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. The English versions of the BSS-RI are available on figshare: https://figshare.com/articles/journal_contribution/__-_Indicator_pdf/29,917,082 The Chinese versions of the BSS-RI are available on figshare: https://figshare.com/articles/journal_contribution/__-_/29,917,304?file = 57,202,103. https://figshare.com/articles/journal_contribution/__-_Indicator_pdf/29917082The Chinese versions of the BSS-RI are available on figshare: https://figshare.com/articles/journal_contribution/__-_/29917304?file=57202103

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: The study was reviewed and approved by the Ethics Committee of Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University (approval number: 2022-K150-01). All methods were performed in accordance with the relevant guidelines and regulations (Declaration of Helsinki). All participants have signed the Informed Consent.
